In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  reconnaissance  mission1 in  April  2011,  the  Government  of  Mongolia 
requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for technical assistance (TA) to develop the 
government bond market. A TA fact-finding mission visited Ulaanbaatar from 27 to 30 June 
2011, during which an understanding was reached on the TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, cost 
estimates, financing plan, implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting 
services. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Despite  extensive  natural  resources,  a  significant  portion  of  Mongolia’s  population 
remains in poverty because it cannot mobilize its economic potential effectively. The most 
serious constraint is the underdevelopment of the financial markets, which cannot facilitate the 
accumulation and efficient allocation of the capital necessary for economic development. To 
overcome this constraint, the government has started several initiatives to develop its financial 
markets. One of these is the development of the government bond market.  
 
3.  A developed government bond market can provide various benefits for the economy. 
With a deep and liquid market for government bonds, governments can reduce funding costs 
and  improve  risk  management.  In  addition,  a  developed  government  bond  market  can 
strengthen the effectiveness of monetary policy by establishing a yield curve through which the 
effects  of  monetary  policy  are  transmitted.  Aside  from  these  macroeconomic  benefits,  the 
development of a government bond market also contributes to the development of related 
financial  markets.  For  example,  establishment  of  the  benchmark  yield  curve  facilitates  the 
development of the corporate bond market. In addition, as risk-free assets, government bonds 
can be the basis for the development of various financial products, including money market 
instruments,  repurchase  agreements,  and  derivatives.  Developed  and  diversified  financial 
markets will enhance the efficiency of financial intermediation through greater competition and 
the  development  of  related  financial  infrastructure.  This  leads  to  a  lowering  of  financial 
transaction costs, which can improve access to credit for small and medium-sized enterprises 
and households and eventually promote economic growth. 
 
4.  Mongolia  urgently  needs  to  develop  an  efficient  government  bond  market.  The 
government plans to issue a significant amount of bonds to fund various public projects, and an 
efficient government bond market would enable the government to reduce the cost and the risk 
related to debt management. The government currently issues debt on an as-needed basis 
without any regular schedule. In the absence of a regular issuance of government bonds, there 
is no established benchmark yield curve in Mongolia. The lack of a proper yield curve hinders 
the proper pricing of financial products and results in the underdevelopment of related financial 
markets such as the corporate bond market. 
 
5.  To develop a government bond market, policy makers need to give careful consideration 
to a number of issues: (i) sound and stable fiscal and monetary policies to secure the credibility 
of the government as a debt issuer; (ii) effective legal, tax, and regulatory infrastructure; (iii) 
efficient market infrastructure for the primary and secondary markets including the auction, 
clearing, settlement, and depository systems; (iv) active and qualified intermediaries such as

2   
brokers and dealers; and (v) a broad investor base including institutional investors. Although the 
government  has  already  taken  a  number  of  necessary  steps,  significant  improvement  is 
required in most of these areas. Since the recent financial crisis, the government has worked 
with international donors to improve its fiscal and monetary policy framework. As regards the 
legal and regulatory framework, the government is continuing to improve its Law on Securities 
and  related  implementing  regulations.  In  late  2010,  the  government  outsourced  the 
management of the Mongolian Stock Exchange (MSE) to upgrade its operation. However, most 
of these improvements are still in progress and far from completion. In addition, there are some 
areas that require further policy action: (i) improving the auction system in the primary market, 
(ii) developing qualified intermediaries, and (iii) broadening the investor base. 
 
6.  Among these three areas, development of the proper auction system in the primary 
government bond market is the most urgent. Currently, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) issues 
government bonds with a maturity of up to 7 years. For the issuance of government bonds, the 
MOF uses auctions through the MSE on an irregular basis.3 Almost all of the amounts issued 
are purchased by the commercial banks at the price set by the MOF, which is unduly low.4 Lack 
of a proper market-based pricing mechanism discourages private investors from purchasing 
government  bonds.5 In  turn,  the  lack  of  investors  hinders  the  development  of  financial 
institutions that intermediate the transaction of government bonds. 
 
7.  The  TA  will  help  to  develop  the  government  bond  auction  system.  A  comparative 
analysis of several options to improve the government bond auction platform needs to be 
conducted. Currently, there are three possible options for the MOF: (i) continuing to use MSE’s 
auction platform, (ii) integrating it with the Bank of Mongolia’s auction platform for central bank 
bills,  and  (iii)  developing  a  new  auction  platform  customized  to  the  MOF’s  needs.  Each 
alternative has its own strengths and weaknesses. To name a few, MSE’s auction system is 
open to all investors including non-banking financial institutions and individual investors while 
BOM’s system is only accessible to banks. However, BOM’s auction system might be more 
efficient and secure than other alternatives in terms of its connectivity to the payment system. 
Meanwhile, the new system can be developed to meet market’s needs most effectively although 
it might cause some concerns on cost and duplication of investment. The detailed strengths and 
weaknesses of each option will be analyzed and then a recommendation will be made for the 
upgrading of the auction platform, either by improving one of the existing systems or designing a 
new system. While upgrading the auction platform, the TA will also give careful consideration to 
enhancing the security of transactions. In addition, the TA will consider how to improve the 
overall auction design, including pricing, scheduling, and control over participants. Finally, the 
TA will also provide capacity development opportunities for MOF staff and market participants. 
 
8.  Besides improving the auction system, long-term issues also need to be addressed. 
Developing qualified intermediaries is important to ensure efficient price discovery and reduce 
the transaction costs for bondholders. Thus, the MOF would like to introduce the primary dealer 
system. However, there is a debate as to whether it is desirable to introduce this system in 
Mongolia at this stage. Therefore, the MOF needs advice on the measures needed to develop 
financial intermediaries, including the primary dealer system. 
                                                 
3  The MOF has no predetermined auction schedule and conducts auctions on an as-needed basis. Therefore, the 
number of auctions conducted has been very volatile. For example, 23 auctions were conducted in 2001 but none 
in 2009. 
4  For example, the yield of the 7-year maturity government bond issued in August 2011 was 9% while the yield of the 
12-week central bank bill was 11.72%. 
5  Although participation in the primary auction is open to all financial institutions and individual investors, only a small 
number of big commercial banks participate in the auction.

3
9.  Broadening the investor base is also critical as its size and diversity can help to increase 
market liquidity through greater competition and a diverse risk appetite. In Mongolia, almost all 
government bonds are purchased by a small number of big commercial banks, which usually 
hold them to maturity. Therefore, it is important for the MOF to develop and implement policies 
that will foster the participation of institutional investors. 
 
10.  For ADB operations in Mongolia, public sector management is a core, crosscutting 
theme to help the government increase the efficiency in managing the abundant revenues that 
mining  generates.  Furthermore,  support  for  public  sector  management  aims  to  improve 
government financial management and aid effectiveness, expand the role of public–private 
partnerships,  combat  corruption,  and  strengthen  the  financial  market  to  support  long-term 
investment. Government bond market development in Mongolia is critical for ADB to achieve 
these  goals,  especially  the  improvement  of  government  financial  management  and  the 
strengthening of the financial market. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA will be developed financial markets based on a more efficient 
government  bond  market.  The  achievement  of  this  impact  will  be  demonstrated  through 
development of the benchmark yield curve and the emergence of various financial products. 
The TA’s outcome will be a functional primary government bond market established. This 
outcome  is  to  be  demonstrated  through  the  regular  issuance  of  government  bonds  and 
increased participation in auctions. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will assist the government in developing the government bond market through 
improving  market  infrastructure  and  broadening  the  investor  base.  As  regards  market 
infrastructure,  the  TA  will  focus  on  upgrading  the  primary  auction  system  and  developing 
financial intermediaries. The TA will conduct a comparative analysis of the various options for 
the primary auction system and provide policy recommendations for improving the current 
system. If necessary, the TA will support the procurement of the new auction software and 
related services from a globally renowned service provider. In addition, the TA will assist the 
MOF in developing the necessary institutional structure, including the primary dealer system, for 
the development of financial intermediaries. It will also support the MOF in addressing the long-
term issue of broadening the investor base for government bonds. During TA implementation, 
various opportunities for capacity development as well as relevant knowledge products will be 
provided for MOF staff and market participants. 
 
13.  The TA will deliver five major outputs: 
 
(i)  Upgraded government bond auction platform. Several options for the MOF 
will be analyzed including the systems operated by the MSE and the Bank of 
Mongolia. Based on the analysis, recommendations will be made on how to 
improve the current auction platform or whether to design a new one. 
(ii)  Improved general auction design. In addition to upgrading the auction platform, 
an enhanced auction design will improve the price discovery process and market 
efficiency.  Various  issues  will  be  covered,  including  pricing,  scheduling,  and 
control over participants.

4   
(iii)  Policies recommended for long-term development of the government bond 
market. Policy recommendations will be made on long-term issues to develop 
the government bond market, such as developing financial intermediaries and 
broadening the investor base. 
(iv)  Capacity developed for government staff and market participants. MOF staff 
and market participants will have opportunities for capacity development through 
training sessions, workshops, and seminars. 
(v)  Knowledge products provided. The TA will produce a short policy note, as well 
as several technical notes, as knowledge products targeting policy makers. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund; and (ii) $500,000 will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund,6 both 
administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office 
accommodation, transportation, office supplies and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  executing  agency  is  the  MOF  and  the  implementing  agency  is  the  Debt 
Management Division in the MOF. The MOF and the Debt Management Division will (i) provide 
the necessary office space, counterpart staff, transportation, and other services to consultants; 
and (ii) arrange meetings for consultants with relevant agencies and organizations. 
 
16.  The TA will engage three international consultants for 20 person-months and three 
national consultants for 20 person-months. The government bond market expert will be the 
team leader. Consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed 
in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time). For equipment, training seminars, and conferences, advance payment facility 
could be used. 
 
17.  The TA is expected to begin in 1 February 2012 and end on 31 December 2013. 
Assembling the TA team and preparing a detailed work plan will be completed within 2 months. 
The TA will then proceed as follows: (i) analysis of the current status of the government bond 
market by month 4, (ii) upgrading of the auction platform by month 10, (iii) recommendations to 
improve the overall auction design by month 13, and (iv) policy recommendations on long-term 
issues such as developing financial intermediaries and broadening the investor base by month 
20. Capacity development opportunities for government staff and market participants will be 
organized during TA implementation. 
 
18.  In addition to the main outputs, the consultants will submit to ADB and the MOF (i) 
inception reports 2 weeks after commencement of their services, (ii) interim progress reports at 
appropriate stages during TA implementation, (iii) draft final reports before the conclusion of the 
contract, and (iv) final reports 2 weeks after receiving comments from the MOF and ADB. All 
reports must be submitted in English.

19.  Major project activities will be regularly monitored and reported on by the MOF and ADB 
administration missions. The consultants’ reports will be presented at workshops and seminars 
organized for the validation of findings. Reports will be made available on the ADB website and 
published in English. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund,  and (ii) ADB administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $500,000 to the Government of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Financial 
Sector Development Partnership Fund for Government Bond Market Development, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Implementation of the study will require 20 person-months of international consultants 
and  20  person-months  of  national  consultants.  Consultants  will  be  hired  individually  in 
accordance with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The team leader and government bond market expert 
will be responsible for the quality and timely completion of the technical assistance (TA) outputs. 
All the consultants will be working under the overall coordination and monitoring of the ADB 
project officer. 
 
A.  Team Leader and Government Bond Market Expert (international, 8 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
2.  The expert (team leader) must possess a good knowledge of and sufficient experience 
in government bond market development. Specifically, the team leader should have expertise in 
market infrastructure and the legal and regulatory framework for the government bond market. A 
strong academic background, with publication of relevant materials, is preferred. The team 
leader will take overall responsibility for the design and coordination of the research outputs. 
The team leader’s specific tasks include: 
 
(i)  preparing a detailed work plan to achieve the outputs of the project; the work 
plan will indicate the targeted tasks and the timing of each task; 
(ii)  coordinating the work of international and national consultants for the quality and 
timely completion of all research outputs; 
(iii)  conducting research on the current status of the government bond market in 
Mongolia,  with  special  attention  to  the  efficiency  of  the  pricing  mechanism 
including the primary auction system, the capacity of  financial intermediaries, 
and the potential of the investor base; 
(iv)  recommending  improvements  in  the  overall  design  of  the  government  bond 
auction system, including pricing, scheduling, and control over participants; 
(v)  conducting research and making policy recommendations on the regulatory and 
legal framework governing the government bond market in terms of investor 
protection and market efficiency; 
(vi)  conducting  research  and  making  policy  recommendations  on  the  clearance, 
settlement,  and  other  related  infrastructure  to  ensure  it  can  guarantee  the 
soundness and validity of bond transactions; 
(vii)  making policy recommendations on long-term issues such as nurturing financial 
intermediaries and broadening the investor base; 
(viii)  introducing international best practices to facilitate comparative studies that are 
relevant for government bond market development in Mongolia; 
(ix)  consulting  the  ADB  project  officer  and  government  officials  to  gather  timely 
feedback to ensure effective implementation of the TA; 
(x)  organizing capacity development opportunities for government staff and market 
participants such as training sessions, seminars, and workshops; and 
(xi)  coordinating with the other consultants and taking responsibility for producing a 
short policy note and several technical notes targeting policy makers.

10  Appendix 3 
B.  Bond Market Infrastructure Expert (international, 7 person-months, intermittent) 
 
3.  The expert must have an in-depth knowledge and solid background in developing bond 
market  infrastructure,  especially  in  the  design  of  a  primary  auction  system  and  related 
infrastructure.  The  expert  will  be  responsible  for  upgrading  the  government  bond  auction 
platform and related infrastructure as well as supporting the team leader in providing policy 
recommendations. The expert’s specific tasks include: 
 
(i)  assessing the current government bond auction platform including a comparison 
of different options such as the Mongolian Stock Exchange system, the Bank of 
Mongolia system, and a new one; 
(ii)  making a recommendation on the upgrading of the auction platform, namely 
whether to improve one of the current platforms or to design a new one; 
(iii)  assisting the team leader in developing policy recommendations on relevant 
issues,  including  the  improvement  of  the  overall  auction  design  and  the 
development  of  related  infrastructure  such  as  the  clearance  and  settlement 
system; 
(iv)  introducing international best practices to facilitate comparative studies that are 
relevant for government bond market development in Mongolia; 
(v)  consulting  the  ADB  project  officer  and  government  officials  to  gather  timely 
feedback to ensure effective implementation of the TA; 
(vi)  assisting  the  team  leader  in  organizing  training  sessions,  seminars,  and 
workshops for government staff and market participants; and 
(vii)  assisting the team leader in producing a policy note through drafting the related 
section and taking responsibility for producing a technical note on related issues. 
 
C.  Capital  Market  Legal  and  Regulatory  Expert  (international,  5  person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
4.  The expert must have an in-depth knowledge of and a solid background in legal and 
regulatory  issues  related  to  the  government  bond  market,  preferably  with  experience  in 
developing regulations for the government bond market. The expert will have responsibility for 
improving the legal and regulatory framework so as to increase the efficiency and security of 
government bond transactions as well as investor protection, and will also support the team 
leader in providing relevant policy recommendations. The expert’s specific tasks include: 
 
(i)  assessing  the  current  status  of  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  the 
government bond market, especially the efficiency and security of government 
bond transactions as well as investor protection; 
(ii)  Improving the legal and regulatory framework and drafting new regulations; 
(iii)  assisting the team leader in developing policy recommendations for relevant 
issues including the improvement of the overall auction design, the development 
of financial intermediaries, and the broadening of the investor base; 
(iv)  introducing international best practices to facilitate comparative studies that are 
relevant for government bond market development in Mongolia; 
(v)  consulting  the  ADB  project  officer  and  government  officials  to  gather  timely 
feedback to ensure effective implementation of the TA; 
(vi)  assisting  the  team  leader  in  organizing  training  sessions,  seminars,  and 
workshops for government staff and market participants; and 
(vii)  assisting the team leader in producing a policy note through drafting the related 
section and taking responsibility for producing a technical note on related issues.

Appendix 3  11 
D.  Bond Market Economist (national, 8 person-months, intermittent) 
 
5.  The economist must possess a good knowledge of finance and capital markets, be fluent 
in English, and preferably have strong expertise in bond market infrastructure and related 
regulation.  The  economist  will  assist  the  team  leader  in  conducting  relevant  tasks.  The 
economist’s specific tasks include: 
 
(i)  providing background information and translating documents into English; 
(ii)  advising the team leader on major constraints on the implementation of potential 
policy measures; 
(iii)  advising the team leader on the appropriateness of policy recommendations in 
relation to (a) the capacity of the executing agency, (b) legal and institutional 
structures in Mongolia, and (c) the capacity of other market participants; 
(iv)  communicating ideas between the consultant team and relevant counterparts 
such as government officials and market participants; and 
(v)  assisting  the  team  leader  in  organizing  training  sessions,  seminars,  and 
workshops. 
 
E.  Bond Trading System Expert (national, 7 person-months, intermittent) 
 
6.  The expert must possess a good knowledge of securities trading systems and related 
infrastructure,  be  fluent  in  English,  and  preferably  have  strong  expertise  in  designing  an 
information technology system. The expert will assist the bond market infrastructure expert in 
conducting relevant tasks. The expert’s specific tasks include: 
 
(i)  providing background information and translating documents into English; 
(ii)  advising the bond market infrastructure expert on the strengths and weaknesses 
of different auction platforms for Mongolia’s financial markets; 
(iii)  advising the bond market infrastructure expert on the appropriateness of policy 
recommendations in relation to (a) the capacity of the executing agency, (b) legal 
and institutional structures in Mongolia, and (c) the capacity of other market 
participants; 
(iv)  communicating  ideas  between  the  consultant  team  and  relevant  government 
officials and market participants; and 
(v)  assisting the team leader and the bond market infrastructure expert in organizing 
training sessions, workshops, and seminars. 
 
F.  Capital Market Lawyer (national, 5 person-months, intermittent) 
 
7.  The lawyer must possess a good knowledge of legal and regulatory issues in capital 
markets, be fluent in English, and preferably have an advanced degree in law and relevant 
working experience. The lawyer will assist the capital market legal and regulatory expert in 
conducting relevant tasks. The lawyer’s specific tasks include: 
 
(i)  providing background information and translating documents into English; 
(ii)  advising  the  capital  market  legal  and  regulatory  expert  on  the  legal  and 
regulatory issues in Mongolia’s government bond market; 
(iii)  advising the capital market legal and regulatory expert on the appropriateness of 
policy recommendations in relation to (a) the capacity of the executing agency, 
(b) legal and institutional structures in Mongolia, and (c) the capacity of other 
market participants;

12  Appendix 3 
(iv)  assisting the team leader and the capital market legal and regulatory expert in 
organizing various capacity development opportunities; and 
(v)  communicating  ideas  between  the  consultant  team  and  relevant  government 
officials.
